Award.AwardTitle: Standard Research: The Collected Papers of Albert Einstein

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This award will support ongoing research, translation, and free online dissemination activities of The Collected Papers of Albert Einstein. The funds would help to support making available in print and online thousands of Einstein documents and Einstein-related material accompanied by in-depth scholarly research. The volumes are an indispensable resource for 20th century science and technology studies, scientists, historians and philosophers of science, but also for the study of European and American history, network and scientific communications, education, science policy, the relation of science, technology, and government and many other areas of inquiry.

Technical Summary

Over the grant period, the editors will prepare 2 documentary volumes and 2 English translation volumes covering the years 1925 through 1929, as part of a series that is projected to reach thirty volumes and ultimately contain more than 30,000 documents and their scholarly annotation. The two volumes will contain approximately 150-200 writings (articles, drafts, lectures) by Einstein as annotated full-text, 800 letters by and to Einstein as annotated full-text, 1,500 letters by and to Einstein in English-language abstracts, references to 1,000 third party primary documents a bibliography of several hundred secondary sources. This work will complement and enhance digital humanities and science initiatives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project makes available in print and on line the vast treasure of scientific, historical, political, and personal documents contained in the papers of Albert Einstein (1879-1955).

During the grant period the international team of collaborators has carried out research, annotation, translation, and publication of:

  • 200 writings (articles, drafts, lectures) by Einstein
  • 1,000 letters by and to Einstein as annotated full-text
  • more than 2,000 additional letters by and to Einstein in English-language abstracts
  • references to 1,000 third party primary documents
  • a bibliography of several hundred secondary sources

The material covered the period 1925 to 1929. One of the major discoveries of interest concerns Einstein's involvement in the development of the new quantum mechanics and with the formulation of a possible unified field theory. The material has revealed his deep involvement in substantive criticism, suggestions, and queries formulated in correspondence with W. Heisenberg, E.Schroedinger, P. Jordan and Max Born. The project has also unveiled manuscripts that Einstein withdrew from publication, especially as a result of exchanges with these colleagues, as well as with Elie Cartan. It also revealed that through the nexus of Paul Ehrenfest's correspondence network, this large group of physicists and their students were in close contact with each other and with Einstein. A picture of "collective" effort and national and international networks of collaboration emerges much more clearly from this in-depth investigation.

Research on Volume 15 uncovered 200 additional documents relevant for this period (an almost 20% increase from about 1,250 to 1,434 documents for the 24 months period in Einstein's life June 1925-May 1927). Moreover, research also uncovered almost 500 previously unknown letters, drafts,petitions and other documents for the period of Volume 16. These are significant results in Einstein scholarship.

Making available thousands of primary historical documents in both original and English versions is one of the major avenues of impact on the history and the philosophy of science, of European political, social, cultural history. The materials and explanatory apparatus provided by the Collected Papers of Albert Einstein has transformed myriad "received" views in these disciplines.

In collaboration with Princeton University Press, the project has made available for free all published volumes of the edition.

The latest can be found at:

http://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/vol14-doc/

http://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/vol14-trans/

https://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/vol15-doc/

https://einsteinpapers.press.princeton.edu/vol15-trans/

Volume 16 of the series will be published in spring 2021.

Over the entire grant period, the Project researchers have uncovered a wealth of material previously unknown and unpublished, including more than 50 writings,interviews, notes, calculations by Einstein.

In addition, we have undertaken a detailed examination of 1,750 pages of calculations for the period 1922 to 1955 on unified field theory.Our collaborators have used the expanded knowledge base to publish peer-reviewd articles and books.  

Over the entire grant period, the Project has trained more than 75 undergraduate students in various techniques of image recognition and examination of calculations on unified field theory and transcription into Latex and PDF. This will constitute an invaluable resource base for future research.

Scholars on the project have given presentations at national and international conferences, workshops and specialized academic departments of history and philosophy of science, physics etc.They have also engaged in presentations at the local community level, in bookstores, schools, bibliographic societies, librarians etc. Our website einstein.caltech.edu has presented news and material of interest on a bi-weekly basis.We have also started a Twitter account that presents important documents and visual materials.

Moreover, the project has provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas; improved the performance, skills, and knowledge base of members of underrepresented groups that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, engineering, and other STEM fields; we have developed and disseminated new educational materials and provided exposure to science and technology for practitioners, teachers, young people, and other members of the public
